repnme.cdata!:
Timor-Leste - First, Second, and Third
            Community Empowerment and Local Governance Projects; and the
            First and Second Agricultural Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community and Local Governance
            Project (CEP I), the Second Community Empowerment Project
            (CEP II), and the Third Community Empowerment and Local
            Governance Project (CEP III) had the following ratings:
            unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and not rated (CEP I), satisfactory (CEP II),
            and satisfactory (CEP III) Grantee performance.  The
            Agricultural Rehabilitation Project had the following
            ratings: moderately satisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact,
            satisfactory Bank performance, and not rated Grantee
            performance.  The Second Agricultural Rehabilitation Project
            had the following ratings: moderately unsatisfactory
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance, and
            satisfactory Grantee performance. Experience with these
            projects highlights the following lessons: 1) With its
            global outreach and the expertise and experience of its
            staff the Bank is well positioned to make a substantial
            contribution to post-conflict reconstruction and
            development.  However, the experience of the three community
            empowerment and the two agriculture rehabilitation projects
            shows that careful thought to suitability of design and
            strategies to country conditions is paramount, especially
            where country capacity is weak; 2) even in the case of
            post-conflict Timor-Leste, where sophisticated monitoring
            and evaluation was impractical, there was a need to have a
            system to track project inputs, outputs, and outcomes and
            provide information about the adaptations needed in project
            design to ensure that the project objectives and activities
            are in keeping with the emerging institutional context and
            the absorptive capacity of the country; 3) particularly in
            post-conflict environments, an approach to capacity building
            that considers the underlying capacity in the country as
            well as how it would be promoted by the various donors is
            critical; and 4) the experience of Timor-Leste highlights
            the critical importance of coordinating multi-agency
            reconstruction efforts more effectively in a newly
            independent post-conflict country.

            EMPOWERMENT PROJECT,TF028376-EAST TIMOR SECOND COMMUNITY
            EMPOWERMENT AND LOCAL GOVERNANCE PROJECT,UN009170-PREP SEC DEV BRF WATER SUP
            DONOR'S CONF,TF051103-EAST TIMOR THIRD COMMUNITY
            EMPOWERMENT AND LOCAL GOVERNANCE PROJECT,TF023824-TFET - AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF050151-TFET - SECOND AGRICULTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Agriculture
            Rehabilitation Project for Timor-Leste was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned: Clearly
            defined results-based indicators, which are easy to monitor,
            facilitate project implementation. Good understanding of
            socio-economic situation, farming systems and livelihood
            opportunities is crucial for design and impact analysis.
            Outcome and output targets need to be realistic. Complexity
            in the design impedes local ownership. Development work is
            to be built on a legislative framework and functioning institutions.

repnme.cdata!:
East Timor - Second Agriculture
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Agriculture Rehabilitation
            Project, aims to improve food security of rural populations,
            and increase agricultural production in selected areas of
            East Timor. Through its components, the project will: 1)
            pilot an approach to strengthen the resilience of poor
            farming communities, by improving the management of natural
            resources, and the diverse sources of income. Through the
            provision of small grants, community proposals will be
            funded against in-kind labor, and materials. Training to
            farmers will include applied technical, and participatory
            methods, as well as monitoring and evaluation of projects;
            2) increase agricultural production in irrigated areas, by
            financing the rehabilitation, and maintenance works on
            community-based irrigation schemes, farm-to-market access
            roads, including larger damaged irrigation schemes. Water
            Users Associations in the irrigated areas will be
            consolidated, and, an irrigation operational policy will be
            developed. All this entails training in irrigation
            management, as well as a monitoring and evaluation criteria;
            3) provide essential services to farmers, to bridge
            transitional difficulties, and will gradually introduce
            private delivery mechanisms, through the development of
            information programs, and the establishment of liaison
            groups, to provide agricultural expertise, and technical
            assistance to farmers, including sustainable animal health
            services; and, 4) finance policy studies, technical
            assistance and incremental operating costs, to support
            project management and capacity building.

repnme.cdata!:
East Timor - Second Agricultural
            Rehabilitation Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Agricultural Rehabilitation
            Project aims to improve and strengthen the agricultural base
            of the rural population who form the majority of East Timor.
            Among the project components, the Pilot Participatory
            Development and Natural Resources Management component
            involves activities which are small in scale, and therefore
            the environmental impact in the short term is not expected
            to be significant. The Rapid Infrastructure Rehabilitation
            component will support community irrigation rehabilitation.
            Such activity may generate dust, local turbidity of
            watercourses, and localized downstream erosion arising from
            river diversion. Also under this component, civil work
            activities will be employed in the rehabilitation of a total
            of 7 medium-scale irrigation schemes. The works will include
            the rehabilitation of main structures and canals, as well as
            secondary and tertiary canals that would provide irrigation
            to an estimated 1,500 hectares. The highest rating for the
            potential environmental impact of the irrigation scheme
            rehabilitation is moderate in intensity and medium-term in
            persistence, and the impacts occur mainly during the
            construction phase of the activity. The operational phase of
            the irrigation scheme is not expected to produce significant
            negative environmental impact. The rest of the project
            components will involve no significant environmental impacts.
